prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The sensitivity requirement of 11 microJy over 7.5 GHz is based on the continuum flux value. Assuming the emission of M60-UCD1 in the radio continuum comes from accretion onto a black hole, we predict the mm flux density to be 0.6 mJy. For a source size of 2" and requested resolution of 0.8", the peak flux density per beam is 0.1 mJy/beam, and sensitivity of 0.011 mJy/beam gives us a S/N of 9.1. This requires a total of 2.27 hours on source.

We ask for one spectral window to be set to the CO (2-1) transition at 230 GHz, to detect the presence of any cool gas in the centre, with a bandwidth of 77 km/s. The other three spectral windows are manually set to cover the continuum frequencies of 214, 216 and 230 GHz, with TDM correlator modes at 2 GHz bandwidth, to detect continuum emission from accretion onto the central black hole. The continuum flux measurement is important to distinguish between the case of a low mass x-ray binary and a central supermassive black hole, as explained in the Scientific Justification.

M60-UCD1 has an angular size of ~2" (~160 pc at 16.5 Mpc distance). The effective radius of the central stellar cluster is R_e=24 pc, which translates to 0.3". We ask for an angular resolution of 0.8" to be able to resolve the emission from the central black hole.

We ask for one spectral window to be set to the CO (2-1) transition at 230 GHz, to detect the presence of any cool gas in the centre, with a bandwidth of 76 km/s. The other three spectral windows are manually set to cover the continuum frequencies of 214, 216 and 230 GHz, with TDM correlator modes at 2 GHz bandwidth, to detect continuum emission from accretion onto the central black hole. The continuum flux measurement is important to distinguish between the case of a low mass x-ray binary and a central supermassive black hole, as explained in the Scientific Justification.

VUCD7 has an angular size of ~2.6" (~210 pc at 16.5 Mpc distance). The effective radius of the central stellar cluster is R_e=105 pc, which translates to 1.3". We ask for an angular resolution of 0.8" to be able to resolve the emission from the central black hole.

The sensitivity requirement of 15 microJy over 7.5 GHz is based on the continuum flux value. Assuming the emission of VUCD7 in the radio continuum comes from accretion onto a black hole, we predict the mm flux density to be 1.53 mJy. For a source size of 2.6" and requested resolution of 0.3", the peak flux density per beam is 0.15 mJy/beam, and a sensitivity of 0.015 mJy/beam gives us a S/N of 10. This requires a total of 1.19 hours on source.

We ask for one spectral window to be set to the CO (2-1) transition at 230 GHz, to detect the presence of any cool gas in the centre, with a bandwidth of 76 km/s. The other three spectral windows are manually set to cover the continuum frequencies of 214, 216 and 230 GHz, with TDM correlator modes at 2 GHz bandwidth, to detect continuum emission from accretion onto the central black hole. The continuum flux measurement is important to distinguish between the case of a low mass x-ray binary and a central supermassive black hole, as explained in the Scientific Justification.

HGHH92-C1 has an angular size of ~2.5" (~46 pc at 3.77 Mpc distance). The effective radius of the central stellar cluster is R_e=23.3 pc, which translates to 1.275". We ask for an angular resolution of 0.8" to be able to resolve the emission from the central black hole.

The sensitivity requirement of 20 microJy over 7.5 GHz is based on the continuum flux value. Assuming the emission of HGHH92-C1 in the radio continuum comes from accretion onto a black hole, we predict the mm flux density to be 1.17 mJy. For a source size of 2.5" and requested resolution of 0.8", the peak flux density per beam is 0.32 mJy/beam, and for a sensitivity of 0.020 mJy/beam then gives us a S/N of 15. This requires a total of 37.29 minutes on source.

We ask for one spectral window to be set to the CO (2-1) transition at 230 GHz, to detect the presence of any cool gas in the centre, with a bandwidth of 77 km/s. The other three spectral windows are manually set to cover the continuum frequencies of 214, 216 and 230 GHz, with TDM correlator modes at 2 GHz bandwidth, to detect continuum emission from accretion onto the central black hole. The continuum flux measurement is important to distinguish between the case of a low mass x-ray binary and a central supermassive black hole, as explained in the Scientific Justification.

F19 has an angular size of ~2" (~195 pc at 20 Mpc distance). The effective radius of the central stellar cluster is R_e=90.6 pc, which translates to 0.93". We ask for an angular resolution of 0.8" to be able to resolve the emission from the central black hole.

The sensitivity requirement of 15 microJy over 7.5 GHz is based on the continuum flux value. Assuming the emission of F19 in the radio continuum comes from accretion onto a black hole, we predict the mm flux density to be 1.16 mJy. For a source size of 2" and requested resolution of 0.8", the peak flux density per beam is 0.19 mJy/beam, and sensitivity of 0.015 mJy/beam gives us a S/N of 12.7. This requires a total of 1.06 hours on source.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe four objects from a new category of Ultracompact Dwarf Galaxies (UCDs), to address an open question if these dense stellar systems contain a supermassive black hole (SMBH) embedded in a gaseous environment and accreting in a similar mode like the Milky Way SMBH. The latter is surrounded by the Nuclear Stellar Cluster (NSC) and gaseous streamers (Kunneriath et al. 2012). Previously we have argued (Czerny et al. 2013; Rozanska et al. 2014) that the Minispiral contains a two-temperature environment that is maintained by Thermal Instability mechanism. For this the presence of the central SMBH, the extent of the nuclear system, and the composition of the interstellar medium are relevant. Nuclear SMBHs may represent a significant fraction of the total mass of the host stellar system, but the presence of the putative massive black hole is still to be confirmed and a potential confusion with a low-mass X-ray binary (LMXB) needs to be excluded. We want to reach this goal by exploring the sources in mm regime (Band 6 continuum and a tentative CO [2-1] line). For the pilot study we selected a sample of 4 UCDs and propose to explore their environment with ALMA.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Site Prague, Astronomical Institute, Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Site Prague, Astronomical Institute, Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic
